name: SylvaSense
tagline: Low cost open source sensing for agroforestry research
body:
# SylvaSense 

This is a work in progress!!

## Setting up

Things you need to get started:

* arduino [uno](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/arduinoBoardUno)
* data logging shield (or equivalent board)
* ds18b20 temperature sensor
* light dependent resistor (ldr)
* Some sort of battery
* Wire
* Heat shrink
* Water/Tamperproof container

### Setting up the arduino

To start I'm using an arduino uno with a string of six light dependent resistors to measure light intensity, and a matching set of six dallas onewire digital temperature sensors (ds18b20).

To get started taking readings from the ldr I referred to instructions on [this](http://communityofrobots.com/tutorial/kawal/how-use-ldr-arduino) page. Using these instructions, I was able to start taking readings from a single ldr within about 2 minutes.

I used a similar set of instructions for the ds18b20 temperature sensor, using the instructions [here](http://www.hobbytronics.co.uk/ds18b20-arduino). Note that it is necessary to install two additional libraries in order to use the ds18b20 with the arduino: the [Dallas Temperature Control Library](http://www.milesburton.com/?title=Dallas_Temperature_Control_Library#One_Wire_Library) and the [OneWire](http://www.pjrc.com/teensy/td_libs_OneWire.html) library.

### To do

* Design circuit for multiple sensors
* incorporate SD card storage
* incorporate realtime clock
* optimise for battery life (Narcolepsy?)
* calculate/trial battery life under different sampling intensity

### Sources of inspiration

* [Vinduino academic paper](http://www.academia.edu/10258579/An_Embedded_System_for_Smart_Vineyard_Agriculture)
* [Make your own gypsum soil moisture sensors](http://unpuntilloalambre.blogspot.com.es/2014/01/gypsum-block-for-soil-moisture-sensor.html)
  * These soil DIY soil sensors are gypsum based, and therefore a vast improvement on other sensors I have seen online which are based on electrodes inserted into bare soil. To build you need:
    * [35 mm hair curlers](http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/huc/view.html?ie=UTF8&newItems=CVQBVDMCXYT1O%2C1)
    * [M3 threaded rod](http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00SJHFUQ0/ref=ox_sc_imb_mini_detail?ie=UTF8&psc=1&smid=A3UZTDMDZ5GUQW)
    * [3D printed caps for the curlers](http://www.thingiverse.com/make:103549). If you have a 3D printer these can be printed by you, otherwise online services exist which can print these for you e.g.:https://www.shapeways.com.
    * Gypsum (plaster of Paris) - [you can make your own](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JUmtgeGc_JA) or [buy](http://www.amazon.co.uk/Loxley-Plaster-of-Paris-1kg/dp/B002L6RIQK) it - it's not expensive. 
* Alternative [soil moisture sensing](http://makezine.com/projects/make-18/garduino-geek-gardening/)
* [More soil moisture sensing](http://www.cheapvegetablegardener.com/how-to-make-cheap-soil-moisture-sensor-2/)
* [Growerbot](http://growerbot.com/)
